thread.title: Under Armour sales top estimates on international momentum, sending shares soaring

title: Under Armour sales top estimates on international momentum, sending shares soaring
text:
Under Armour sales top estimates on international momentum, sending shares soaring Sales in international markets climbed 47%, representing 23% of total sales. Under Armour managed to sell more apparel, footwear and accessories during the holiday season.   Join the Nation's Conversation To   Under Armour sales top estimates on international momentum, sending shares soaring Lauren Thomas, CNBC Published 8:12 a.m. ET Feb. 13, 2018 | Updated 11:42 a.m. ET Feb. 13, 2018 Jacksonville Jaguars running back T.J. Yeldon warms up wearing Under Armour cleats before an NFL football game against the Seattle Seahawks in Jacksonville, Fla. Under Armour reports financial results Tuesday, Feb. 13, 2018. (Photo: Stephen B. Morton, AP) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Under Armour shares soared more than 13% Tuesday morning after the company reported sales that topped analysts' expectations, fueled largely by growth outside of North America. Total revenue in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017 climbed 5% to $1.37 billion. Analysts were expecting revenue of $1.31 billion, according to a Thomson Reuters survey. Sales in international markets (i.e. Latin America, Asia-Pacific and Europe, the Middle East and Africa) climbed 47%, representing 23% of total sales. The company reported a net loss of $88 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with net income of $103 million, or 23 cents per share, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, Under Armour earned 0 cents in the fourth quarter, matching analysts' estimates. The company incurred a one-time charge this quarter due to new U.S. tax legislation. "2017 was a catalyst for us to begin strategically transforming Under Armour into an operationally excellent company," CEO Kevin Plank said in a statement. "Our fourth quarter and full year results demonstrate that the tough decisions we're making are generating the stability necessary to create a more consistent and predictable path to deliver long-term value to our shareholders." Late last year , Under Armour reported third-quarter sales that fell short of analysts' expectations, as the company booked an $85 million charge for restructuring efforts. It has since trimmed about 2% of its global workforce and has considered exiting smaller categories, such as fishing. 
"2017 was a catalyst for us to begin strategically transforming Under Armour into an operationally excellent company," CEO Kevin Plank said in a statement (Photo: Rick Maiman, AP) The Baltimore-based retailer has suffered in North America, in particular, where demand for its apparel merchandise hasn't been as strong. That's against a backdrop of brands such as Adidas, Nike , Lululemon and up-starts like Outdoor Voices stealing market share. In the fourth quarter, though, which includes the holiday season, Under Armour managed to sell more apparel, footwear and accessories. Revenue in those divisions climbed, 2.5%, 9.5% and 6.1%, respectively. The company said some of its strongest businesses are still men's training and running shoes. Plank has said one area where the company is still focused on growing is selling directly to consumers internationally. The company recently announced a handful of new hires to help meet those goals. North American sales in the fourth quarter fell 4%, but direct-to-consumer revenue climbed 11% overall. Under Armour continues to build out its website to meet these new growth targets, as its wholesale revenues decline. Looking to fiscal 2018, Under Armour said it anticipates sales to grow at a low-single-digit percentage rate, which incorporates a mid-single-digit decline in North American sales and growth internationally of more than 25%. The company is expecting to incur additional restructuring charges of between $110 million and $130 million later this year, which are related to terminating leases and closing some of its facilities — all part of ongoing restructuring plans. As of Monday's market close, Under Armour shares are down about 34% from a year ago. © CNBC is a USA TODAY content partner offering financial news and commentary.
